title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0001
text: Which package contains the Map interface?
explanation: The Map interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0002
text: Which of the following best describes the Map interface?

options.text: A collection that maps keys to values
A collection that stores elements in order
A collection that stores unique elements only
A collection that allows duplicate keys

explanation: The Map interface represents a collection that maps unique keys to values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about keys in a Map?
explanation: Keys in a Map must be unique; duplicate keys overwrite existing entries.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0004
text: Which of the following is true about values in a Map?
explanation: Values in a Map can be duplicated, but keys must be unique.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0005
text: Which of the following classes implement the Map interface?
explanation: HashMap, TreeMap, LinkedHashMap, and Hashtable are implementations of the Map interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap?

options.text: HashMap does not maintain insertion order

explanation: HashMap does not maintain insertion order; it is based on hashing.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedHashMap?
explanation: LinkedHashMap maintains insertion order using a linked list internally.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap?

options.text: TreeMap stores keys in sorted order

explanation: TreeMap stores keys in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0009
text: Which of the following is true about Hashtable?
explanation: Hashtable is synchronized and does not allow null keys or values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and null keys?

options.text: HashMap does not allow null keys

explanation: HashMap allows one null key and multiple null values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap and null keys?

options.text: TreeMap does not allow null keys

explanation: TreeMap does not allow null keys because it uses natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods returns the number of key-value mappings in a Map?
explanation: The size() method returns the number of key-value mappings in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0013
text: Which of the following methods checks if a key exists in a Map?
explanation: The containsKey(Object key) method checks if a specific key exists in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0014
text: Which of the following methods checks if a value exists in a Map?
explanation: The containsValue(Object value) method checks if a specific value exists in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0015
text: Which of the following methods retrieves a value for a given key?
explanation: The get(Object key) method retrieves the value associated with the specified key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0016
text: Which of the following methods inserts a key-value pair into a Map?
explanation: The put(K key, V value) method inserts a key-value pair into the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0017
text: Which of the following methods removes a key-value pair from a Map?
explanation: The remove(Object key) method removes the mapping for the specified key.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0018
text: Which of the following methods removes all mappings from a Map?
explanation: The clear() method removes all key-value mappings from the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0019
text: Which of the following methods returns a Set view of the keys in a Map?
explanation: The keySet() method returns a Set view of the keys contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0020
text: Which of the following methods returns a Collection view of the values in a Map?
explanation: The values() method returns a Collection view of the values contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0021
text: Which of the following methods returns a Set view of the key-value mappings in a Map?
explanation: The entrySet() method returns a Set view of the key-value mappings contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about Map and null values in HashMap?

options.text: HashMap allows only one null value
HashMap does not allow null values

explanation: HashMap allows one null key and multiple null values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about Map and null keys in Hashtable?

options.text: Hashtable does not allow null keys

explanation: Hashtable does not allow null keys or values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about Map and synchronization?

options.text: Map is not synchronized by default

explanation: Map is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedMap().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0025
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a Map?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedMap() method returns a synchronized (thread-safe) map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0026
text: Which of the following is a thread-safe implementation of Map?
explanation: ConcurrentHashMap is a thread-safe implementation of the Map interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about Map and ordering in LinkedHashMap?
explanation: LinkedHashMap maintains insertion order using a linked list internally.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about Map and ordering in TreeMap?

options.text: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order

explanation: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about Map and iteration order in HashMap?

options.text: HashMap does not maintain any order

explanation: HashMap does not maintain any order of its elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about Map and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most Map implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most Map implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about Map and entrySet()?

options.text: entrySet() returns a Set view of key-value pairs
entrySet() returns a List view of keys
entrySet() returns a Collection of values
entrySet() returns a Map of entries

explanation: The entrySet() method returns a Set view of the key-value pairs contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about Map and keySet()?

options.text: keySet() returns a Set view of keys
keySet() returns a List view of keys
keySet() returns a Collection of values
keySet() returns a Map of keys

explanation: The keySet() method returns a Set view of the keys contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about Map and values()?

options.text: values() returns a Collection view of values
values() returns a Set view of values
values() returns a Map of values
values() returns a List of keys

explanation: The values() method returns a Collection view of the values contained in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about Map and putIfAbsent()?

options.text: putIfAbsent() adds a key-value pair only if the key is not already present

explanation: The putIfAbsent() method adds a key-value pair only if the key is not already present.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about Map and replace()?

options.text: replace() updates the value for a given key if it exists
replace() adds a new key-value pair

explanation: The replace() method updates the value for a given key if it exists.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about Map and computeIfAbsent()?

options.text: computeIfAbsent() computes a value if the key is not present

explanation: The computeIfAbsent() method computes a value for a key if it is not already present.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about Map and computeIfPresent()?

options.text: computeIfPresent() computes a new value if the key is present
computeIfPresent() adds a new key-value pair

explanation: The computeIfPresent() method computes a new value for a key if it is already present.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about Map and merge()?

options.text: merge() combines values for a given key using a remapping function

explanation: The merge() method combines values for a given key using a remapping function.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about Map and forEach()?

options.text: forEach() performs an action for each key-value pair

explanation: The forEach() method performs the given action for each key-value pair in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about Map and getOrDefault()?

options.text: getOrDefault() returns a default value if the key is not found
getOrDefault() throws an exception if the key is not found

explanation: The getOrDefault() method returns a default value if the key is not found in the map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about Map and replaceAll()?

options.text: replaceAll() replaces each value using a given function

explanation: The replaceAll() method replaces each value using the given function.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about Map and entry iteration?

options.text: entrySet() can be used to iterate over key-value pairs
keySet() can be used to iterate over values
values() can be used to iterate over keys

explanation: The entrySet() method provides a Set view that can be used to iterate over key-value pairs.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about Map and immutability?
explanation: The Map.of() method introduced in Java 9 creates an immutable map.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about Map.of() and null keys?

options.text: Map.of() does not allow null keys or values

explanation: The Map.of() method does not allow null keys or values and throws NullPointerException if null is passed.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about Map and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares maps based on key-value pairs
equals() compares maps based on order
equals() compares maps based on references
equals() compares maps based on hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares maps based on their key-value pairs, not order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about Map and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() is based on the key-value pairs
hashCode() is based only on keys

explanation: The hashCode() method of a Map is based on its key-value pairs.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about Map and ConcurrentModificationException?

options.text: Most Map iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException

explanation: Most Map iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about Map and ConcurrentHashMap?

options.text: ConcurrentHashMap is thread-safe and does not allow null keys or values

explanation: ConcurrentHashMap is thread-safe and does not allow null keys or values.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about Map and WeakHashMap?

options.text: WeakHashMap uses weak references for keys
WeakHashMap uses strong references for keys
WeakHashMap does not allow null keys

explanation: WeakHashMap uses weak references for keys, allowing them to be garbage collected when not referenced elsewhere.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkMap - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Map interface?

options.text: A collection that maps unique keys to values
A collection that stores elements in order
A collection that allows duplicate keys
A collection that stores only values

explanation: The Map interface represents a collection that maps unique keys to values.
